revision.text:
[[File:Facebook_-_Update_Your_Name_notification.jpg|thumb|right|[[Facebook]]'s [[Facebook features#Notification|notification]] to "update your name"]] The '''Facebook real-name policy controversy''' refers to the controversy over [[Social networking service|social networking]] site [[Facebook]]{{'}}s "[[real-name system]]" dictating how people register their accounts and configure their [[user profile]]s. The controversy stems from a policy that those who have been adversely affected describe as penalizing users who are in fact using their real names which Facebook has nevertheless deemed to be "fake", while simultaneously allowing anyone to create fake yet plausible-sounding names, as well as obviously implausible-sounding names comprising word combinations that Facebook's software fails to recognize as unlikely to be real because their alleged nonstandard spelling or confusion with fictional characters. Facebook furthermore prohibits users from accurately representing names which according to the site have "too many words", and prohibits initializing first names, preventing users who do so in real life from formatting their own names as they see fit. == Background == The social networking website [[Facebook]] has maintained the [[real-name system]] policy for user profiles. According to Facebook, the real-name policy stems from the position "that way, you always know who you're connecting with. This helps keep our community safe."{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/09/16/living/facebook-name-policy/ |title=Facebook 'real name' policy stirs questions around identity |last=Grinberg |first=Emanuella |date=September 18, 2014 |publisher=[[CNN]] |accessdate=October 21, 2014}}{{cite web |url=https://www.facebook.com/help/112146705538576|title=What names are allowed on Facebook?|last=|first=|date=|publisher=[[Facebook]] |accessdate=October 21, 2014}} Likewise per this policy, a "real name" is defined by "your real name as it would be listed on your credit card, driver's license or student ID."{{cite news |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/facebook-apologizes-for-real-name-policy-2014-10|title=Facebook Apologizes For 'Real Name' Policy That Forced Drag Queens To Change Their Profiles|last=Levy|first=Karyne|date=October 1, 2014|work=[[Business Insider]] |accessdate=October 21, 2014}} In August 2012, Facebook estimated that more than 83 million Facebook accounts are fake accounts.{{cite news |title=Facebook: About 83 million accounts are fake |work=[[USA Today]] |url=https://www.usatoday.com/tech/news/story/2012-08-03/cnbc-facebook-fake-accounts/56759964/1 |accessdate=August 4, 2012 |date=August 3, 2012}} As a result of this revelation, the share price of Facebook dropped below $20.{{cite news |title=Facebook share price slumps below $20 amid fake account flap |work=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2012/aug/02/facebook-share-price-slumps-20-dollars |accessdate=August 4, 2012 |location=London |first=Dominic |last=Rushe |date=August 2, 2012}} Facebook has asserted that "authentic identity is important to the Facebook experience, and our goal is that every account on Facebook should represent a real person." ==Affected users== ===Ethnic groups=== ====Native Americans==== [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]] have been repeatedly targeted due to Facebook's policy.{{cite news|last1=Holpuck|first1=Amanda|title=Facebook still suspending Native Americans over 'real name' policy|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2015/feb/16/facebook-real-name-policy-suspends-native-americans|accessdate=6 March 2015|publisher=Guardian}} *Robin Kills The Enemy, a resident of the [[Sioux]] Rosebud reservation in South Dakota, found that when she tried to register her surname in its normal format, the site would not let her use them, so she resorted to combining the three words, spelling them as one word. After having been a member for some time, she eventually contacted the site in an attempt to have her surname spelled as it actually is in real life. However, after reaching out to Facebook, they instead deactivated her account without explanation. When she was finally able to make contact with an actual employee, they wrote back telling her "Fake names are a violation of our Terms of Use. Facebook requires users to provide their full first and last names". She eventually managed to have her account reinstated; however, users with the surname Kills The Enemy are, as of 2015, still required by Facebook to spell their surname without spaces as a single word.{{cite web|last1=Ramos|first1=Nestor|title=Facebook no friend to American Indian names |url=http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2009/02/16/facebook-no-friend-american-indian-names-82895|website=Indian Country Today media network}} *Shane Creepingbear, an Oklahoman member of the [[Kiowa]] tribe, reported that he had been "kicked off" of Facebook on [[Columbus Day]] for having a supposedly fake name.{{cite web|last1=McAteer|first1=Ollie|title=Native Americans booted off Facebook for having ‘fake’ names like Creepingbear|url=http://metro.co.uk/2015/02/11/native-americans-booted-off-facebook-for-having-fake-names-like-creepingbear-5057955/|website=Metro}} *Lance Brown Eyes, an [[Oglala Lakota|Oglala]], found that his account had been suspended; when he was able to send in documentation to Facebook proving his identity, Facebook reinstated his account, but changed his name to "Lance Brown".{{cite web|last1=Russon|first1=Mary-Ann|title=Facebook fail: Native Americans keep being accused of using fake names|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/facebook-fail-native-americans-keep-being-accused-using-fake-names-1487378|website=International Business Times}} *Dana Lone Hill, a member of the [[Lakota people|Lakota]] tribe who had been a registered Facebook user for several years, discovered one day that she had been locked out of her account. A message from Facebook said "it looks like the name on your Facebook account may not be your authentic name". After a week, during which she had to send in her personal documentation to Facebook, her account access was restored. She has since threatened a class-action lawsuit on behalf of Native Americans against Facebook due to how it exercises its name policies. A number of Native Americans have objected to Facebook's inquiries into their names, and to Facebook's request that they provide proof of identification or other documentation in order to use the service.{{cite news|last1=Phillip| first1=Abby| title=Online ‘authenticity’ and how Facebook's ‘real name’ policy hurts Native Americans | date=October 2, 2014|accessdate=October 5, 2015|url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2015/02/10/online-authenticity-and-how-facebooks-real-name-policy-hurts-native-americans/}} Native American activists claimed to be planning to file a [[class action lawsuit]] against Facebook regarding the 'real name' policy.{{cite news|last1=Holpuck|first1=Amanda|title=Native American activist to sue Facebook over site's 'real name' policy|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2015/feb/19/native-american-activist-facebook-lawsuit-real-name|publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited|work=The Guardian|accessdate=6 March 2015}} ====Japanese==== In 2008, a woman in Japan named Hiroko Yoda had her Facebook account suspended over her [[Yoda_(disambiguation)|surname]], which is common in Japan, being confused with a [[Star Wars]] character of the [[Yoda|same name]].{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/howaboutthat/2632170/Woman-called-Yoda-blocked-from-Facebook.html|title=Woman called Yoda blocked from Facebook|first=Matthew|last=Moore|date=27 August 2008|publisher=|via=www.telegraph.co.uk}} ====Irish==== The [[Dublin]] branch of the [[Irish language]] rights group, Misneach, started a [[Change.org]] [[online petition]] to demand the right to use Irish names on Facebook and protested outside Facebook's European headquarters in Dublin on October 7, 2015.{{cite news |url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/ireland/irish-news/protest-at-dublin-facebook-hq-over-real-name-policy-1.2345414 |title=Protest at Dublin Facebook HQ over ‘real-name’ policy |last=Tracer |first=Dan |date=September 9, 2015 |work=[[Irish Times]] |accessdate=September 9, 2015}} ====Scottish Gaelic==== In 2015, one Gaelic-speaking retired policeman won the right to use his Gaelic name on Facebook, even though it was not his legal name. Some Scottish Gaelic surnames, such as NicIllAnndrais, contain more than two capital letters and are still disallowed by Facebook.{{cite news|title=Man wins Facebook battle over ‘fake’ Gaelic name|url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/odd/man-wins-facebook-battle-over-fake-gaelic-name-1-3702815|date=26 February 2015|website=www.scotsman.com|accessdate=31 October 2017|language=en}} ====Chamoru==== In the Spanish-influenced indigenous [[Chamoru]] culture of the [[Marianas]], the standard naming convention has historically been for a person to use their mother's [[maiden name]] as their middle name. (Chamoru culture, having been colonized by Spain, went through a period where indigenous names and naming conventions were forcibly eradicated and replaced by what the conquering Spanish deemed acceptable.) Furthermore, using one's full name rather than simply the first and last is commonplace, if only for disambiguation purposes due to a relatively small pool of surnames. Therefore, middle names such as De Leon Guerrero and De La Cruz are frequently encountered. However, attempting to register such names as one's middle name results in a message telling users that "Names can't have too many words." Therefore, many Chamoru users are forced to either run all of the words together as if they were one single word, or to initialize each word to a common acronym such as DLG or DLC. In cases where the acronym is employed, Facebook automatically changes to lower-case all letters except the first. (Use of periods, e.g. D.L.G., will result in a message telling users that "Profile names can't have too many periods.") Therefore, someone commonly known in real life by a name such as Mary De Leon Guerrero Mafnas would have to resort to using what on Facebook would end up being "Mary Dlg Mafnas". The message is not accompanied by an option to challenge/appeal the restriction or to send Facebook documentation that the format is how one normally formats their name in real life. ====Vietnamese==== In January 2015, a 23-year-old Australian bank employee claiming to be named Phuc Dat Bich posted a photo of his passport identification page to Facebook, protesting that the company had unfairly shut down his account for being "false and misleading".{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-australia-34897404|title=Phuc Dat Bich: Australian with 'misleading' name thanks supporters|date=November 23, 2015|accessdate=November 23, 2015|work=BBC}} "Is it because I'm Asian? Is it?" he asked. The BBC reported that in Vietnamese the name is pronounced similarly to "Phoo Da Bi" (IPA: [[Help:IPA/Vietnamese|{{ipa|/fukp˦˥ ɗat˩ ɓic˦˥/}}]]). After his reinstatement, Bich posted a thank you note to supportive Facebook fans, stating he was "glad and honoured to be able to make people happy by simply making them laugh at something that appears outrageous and ridiculous". Subsequently "Phuc Dat" published a further message admitting it was a hoax.{{cite news|title=Phuc Dat Bich admits hoax in Facebook name battle|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-australia-34918491|accessdate=25 November 2015|publisher=BBC|date=25 November 2015}} ====Tamils==== Tamils do not have surnames: They have their father or mother or both father and mother's first name as initials.{{cite news|url=https://bumpahead.net/tamil-name-structure-10dd63730563|title=Tamil name structure… |author=moulee|date=19 July 2009|publisher=bumpahead.net|accessdate=15 April 2018}} This standard naming practice has not been acknowledged by Facebook.{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/opinion/op-ed/facebook-should-scrap-its-regressive-real-names-policy/article7797302.ece|title=Really harassed by Facebook’s ‘real names’|author=G. Sampath|date=24 October 2015|publisher=The Hindu|accessdate=15 April 2018|via=www.thehindu.com}} ===Transgender users=== Facebook's real-name policy does not reflect adopted names or [[pseudonym]]s used by the [[transgender]] community, and has led to suspending users with real names that might be thought to be fake.{{cite news|agency=Associated Press| url=http://articles.sfgate.com/2009-05-25/business/20872135_1_accounts-with-fake-names-facebook-facebook-guidelines-and-features|work=The San Francisco Chronicle|first=Barbara|last=Ortutay|date=May 25, 2009|title=Real users caught in Facebook fake-name purge|accessdate=October 22, 2014}} A user via the anonymous [[Android (operating system)|Android]] and [[iOS]] app [[Secret (app)|Secret]] began reporting "fake names" which caused user profiles to be suspended, specifically targeting the [[stage name]]s of [[drag queen]]s.{{cite news|last1=Holpuck|first1=Amanda|title=Facebook still freezing accounts despite apology to drag queens over 'real names.'|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/oct/17/facebook-still-freezing-accounts-despite-apology-drag-queens-real-names|accessdate=6 March 2015}} Transgender people have also been affected by the policy, including one former Facebook employee who initiated development on Facebook's custom gender options, who was suspended on the day the [[Supreme Court of the United States]] ruled in ''[[Obergefell v. Hodges]]'' that same-sex marriage bans were unconstitutional.{{cite news|url=https://medium.com/@zip/my-name-is-only-real-enough-to-work-at-facebook-not-to-use-on-the-site-c37daf3f4b03|title=My name is only real enough to work at Facebook, not use on the site|publisher=[[Medium.com]]|author=Zip|date=June 27, 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.pinknews.co.uk/2015/06/28/woman-responsible-for-facebook-gender-options-kicked-off-for-violating-real-names-policy/|title=Woman responsible for Facebook gender options kicked off for violating real names policy|date=June 28, 2015|first=Naith|last=Payton|publisher=[[Pink News]]}} According to gender non-conforming activist D. Dragonetti, Facebook even disregarded their government identification when supplied.{{Better source|date=March 2015|reason=Daily Dot. This is an opinion piece. Author admits the article is about his/her personal experience, and it may or may not be completely factual or verifiable}}{{cite news|last1=Dragonetti| first1=D.| title=Is Facebook easing up on its 'real names' policy—or cracking down? | work=[[The Daily Dot]]|date=October 20, 2014|accessdate=October 23, 2014|url= http://www.dailydot.com/opinion/facebook-real-names-cracking-down-transgender/}} On October 1, 2014, [[Chris Cox (Facebook)|Chris Cox]], Chief Product Officer at Facebook, offered an apology to the LGBT community and drag kings and queens:
In the two weeks since the real-name policy issues surfaced, we've had the chance to hear from many of you in these communities and understand the policy more clearly as you experience it. We've also come to understand how painful this has been. We owe you a better service and a better experience using Facebook, and we're going to fix the way this policy gets handled so everyone affected here can go back to using Facebook as you were.{{cite web |url=https://www.facebook.com/chris.cox/posts/10101301777354543|title=Chris Cox - I want to apologize to the affected community of drag...|last=Cox|first=Chris|date=October 1, 2014|publisher=[[Facebook]] |accessdate=October 22, 2014}}
=== Users target of religious persecution === Secular, atheist, agnostic, humanist, or users who comment or blog expressing views critical of particular religions, sects or religion in general, as well as religious people who express the opposing views critical of atheism or agnosticism very often have a legitimate need to use an alias. Some of these users could suffer rejection, retaliation or violence if their views – contrary to those of their family, friends or community – are known. In some cases, secular bloggers are exposed to imprisonment by an intolerant government, violent attacks in the street or even being killed by religious fanatics. Examples are the incarceration of activist and blogger [[Raif Badawi]] in Saudi Arabia and a string of attacks and murders of secular activists in [[Attacks by Islamic extremists in Bangladesh|Bangladesh]] or Pakistan.{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/abdullah-sharif/pakistans-religious-extremism_b_9577338.html|title=Pakistan's Religious Extremism: A World Menace|first=Abdullah|last=Sharif|date=1 April 2016|website=huffingtonpost.com}} == Reaction == International non-profit [[digital rights]] group [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] stated they were "alarmed to hear that Facebook's 'real name' policy is disproportionately affecting the LGBTQ community."{{cite web |url=https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2014/09/facebooks-real-name-policy-can-cause-real-world-harm-lgbtq-community |title=Facebook's 'Real Name' Policy Can Cause Real-World Harm for the LGBTQ Community |last1=Kayyali |last2=York |first1=Nadia |first2=Jillian |date=September 16, 2014 |publisher=[[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] |accessdate=October 22, 2014}} [[Online magazine]] ''[[Queerty]]'' called Facebook's policy "a frankly creepy overreach of authority", adding "There are a million reasons why someone would choose to self-identify with a name other than the one that's printed on their birth certificate. And really, it's absolutely none of your business in the first place."{{cite news |url=http://www.queerty.com/facebook-targeting-drag-queens-forcing-them-to-use-their-legal-names-20140911 |title=Facebook Targeting Drag Queens, Forcing Them To Use Their Legal Names |last=Tracer |first=Dan |date=September 11, 2014 |work=[[Queerty]] |accessdate=October 22, 2014}} In an interview for MAGE Magazine, Second Life entrepreneur Jennifer Ceara Firehawk stated: "If we are not using our page to abuse or grief others they just need to leave us be. We are not hurting anyone… FB does not realize some SL people earn lindens to turn into RL (real life) money and that is how they make a living. Once you force a person to change the SL name they will lose money due to not being able to find them on FB or SL as they may use FB for their buisness [sic] or advertise. So they end up losing buisness [sic] and money."{{cite magazine|url=http://0zymandius.wix.com/magemagazine#!September-18-The-Day-F-Book-killed-the-King-Part-1/c112t/55fc2bae0cf256c0bf936f60|title=The Day F Book killed the King : Part 1|date=September 18, 2015|first=Ian|last=Thomson|magazine=MAGE Magazine}} [[Seattle]] [[Drag (clothing)|drag performer]] Olivia LaGarce started a [[Change.org]] [[online petition]] titled "Allow performers to use their stage names on their Facebook accounts!" == Compromise to protect those with special circumstances == On December 15, 2015, Facebook announced in a press release{{cite web |url=http://newsroom.fb.com/news/2015/12/community-support-fyi-improving-the-names-process-on-facebook/|title=Community Support FYI: Improving the Names Process on Facebook |last1=Osofsky |first1=Jason |last2=Gage |first2=Todd |date=December 15, 2015 |website=Facebook Newsroom |publisher=Facebook |access-date=December 16, 2015}} that it would be providing a compromise to its real name policy after protests from groups such as the gay/lesbian community and abuse victims.{{cite web |url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/sci-tech/facebook-modifies-real-names-policy-testing-use-of-assumed-names-1.2702400 |title=Facebook modifies 'real names' policy, testing use of assumed names |last=AFP |date=December 16, 2015 |website=CTV News |publisher=Bell Media |access-date=December 16, 2015}} The site is developing a protocol that will allow members to provide specifics as to their "special circumstance" or "unique situation" with a request to use pseudonyms, subject to verification of their true identities. At that time, this was already being tested in the U.S. Product manager Todd Gage and vice president of global operations Justin Osofsky also promised a new method for reducing the number of members who must go through ID verification while ensuring the safety of others on Facebook. The fake name reporting procedure will also be modified, forcing anyone who makes such an allegation to provide specifics that would be investigated and giving the accused individual time to dispute the allegation.{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/dec/15/facebook-change-controversial-real-name-policy?subid=17310058&CMP=EMCNEWEML6619I2 |title=Facebook changes controversial 'real name' policy in wake of criticism |last1=Holpuch |first1=Amanda |date=December 15, 2015 |website=The Guardian |publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited |access-date=December 16, 2015}} This measure was criticised by the Electronic Frontier Foundation, who pointed out that it forces the most vulnerable users to reveal intimate details of their personal lives. {{cite web|url=https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2015/12/changes-facebooks-real-names-policy-still-dont-fix-problem|title=Changes to Facebook’s "Real Names" Policy Still Don’t Fix the Problem}} Furthermore, as of January 2018, there is no evidence in Facebook's policies that this measure was ever implemented.{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/help/229715077154790?helpref=related|title=What other names are allowed on Facebook?|publisher=Facebook|access-date=May 6, 2017}} == List of notable Facebook accounts suspended == *[[Bebe Sweetbriar]]{{cite news |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/business/ci_26536780/san-francisco-supervisor-calls-facebook-drag-queens-meet |title=San Francisco supervisor calls for Facebook, drag queens to meet over profile name crackdown|last= |first= |date= September 15, 2014|work=[[San Jose Mercury News]] |accessdate=October 22, 2014}} *[[Heklina]]{{cite web |url=http://dragaholic.com/2014/09/senora-oso-lady-bear-responds-facebook-name-change-controversy/|title=Senora Oso Responde: "Lady Bear" Responds to the Facebook Name Change Game|last=|first=|date=September 13, 2014|publisher=Dragaholic|accessdate=October 22, 2014}} *[[Sister Roma]]{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-29175102|title=Drag queens in Facebook name row|last=Lee|first=Dave|date=September 12, 2014|publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=October 22, 2014}}{{cite news |url=http://www.thestranger.com/slog/archives/2014/09/26/facebook-fails-to-explain-its-discriminatory-and-dangerous-real-names-policy&view=comments|title=Facebook Fails to Explain Its Discriminatory and Dangerous 'Real Names' Policy|last=Schmader|first=David|date=September 26, 2014|work=[[The Stranger (newspaper)|The Stranger]] |accessdate=October 22, 2014}}{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/20/sister-roma-facebook_n_5854116.html |title=Sister Roma, Drag Performer, Talks About Leading Fight Against Facebook Name Policy |last=Signorile |first=Michelangelo |date=September 20, 2014 |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |accessdate=September 20, 2014}} *[[R. U. Sirius]]{{Cite web|title = New World Notes: Facebook Ironically Blocks Internet Pioneer for Using Long-Established Pseudonym "R.U. Sirius" on Facebook|url = http://nwn.blogs.com/nwn/2015/10/ru-sirius-facebook-ken-goffman.html|website = nwn.blogs.com|accessdate = 2015-11-15}}{{Cite web|title = Jon Lebkowsky - Frustrating - my friend Ken 'RU Sirius'... {{!}} Facebook|url = https://www.facebook.com/jonlebkowsky/posts/10156233716840074|website = www.facebook.com|accessdate = 2015-11-15}} == See also == *[[Criticism of Facebook]] *[[Nymwars]] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * {{cite journal|last1=Haimson|first1=Oliver L.|last2=Hoffmann|first2=Anna Lauren|title=Constructing and enforcing 'authentic' identity online: Facebook, real names, and non-normative identities|journal=[[First Monday (journal)|First Monday]] |date=2016|volume=21 |issue=6| doi=10.5210/fm.v21i6.6791 | doi-access =free}} * {{cite journal|last1=MacAulay|first1=Maggie|last2=Moldes|first2=Marcos Daniel|title=Queen don't compute: reading and casting shade on Facebook's real names policy|journal=[[Critical Studies in Media Communication]]|date=2016|volume=33|issue=1|pages=6–22|doi=10.1080/15295036.2015.1129430}} {{Facebook navbox}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Facebook real-name policy controversy}} [[Category:21st-century controversies]] [[Category:Human names]] [[Category:Identity management]] [[Category:Internet privacy]] [[Category:Pseudonyms]] [[Category:Naming controversies]] [[Category:Facebook criticisms and controversies|Real-name policy]]

{{redirect|Bernard Ryan|the writer|Bernard Ryan Jr.}} [[Image:Plaque on the Graves of the Forgotten Ten.jpg|thumb|Plaque placed by the Irish Government on the graves of the Volunteers]] The '''Forgotten Ten''' ({{lang-ga|An Deichniúr Dearmadta}})<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wn.com/the_forgotten_ten__an_deichni%C3%BAr_dearmadta_part_1|title=The Forgotten Ten An Deichniúr Dearmadta Part 1|work=World News|accessdate=3 November 2015}}</ref> is the term applied to ten members of the [[Irish Republican Army]] who were executed in [[Mountjoy Prison]], [[Dublin]] by British forces following [[court martial|courts martial]] from 1920–21 during the [[Irish War of Independence]].
Based upon military law at the time, they were buried within the prison precincts, their graves unmarked in the [[Consecration|unconsecrated ground]]. The names of the Forgotten Ten are [[Kevin Barry]], [[Patrick Moran (Irish republican)|Patrick Moran]], [[Frank Flood]], [[Thomas Whelan]], [[Thomas Traynor]], [[Patrick Doyle (Irish republican)|Patrick Doyle]], [[Edmond Foley]], Thomas Bryan, Bernard Ryan, and Patrick Maher.<ref>[http://www.nga.ie/history.htm A Brief History Of The National Graves Association] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071120173433/http://www.nga.ie/history.htm |date=November 20, 2007 }}, nga.ie; accessed 19 November 2015.</ref>
The executioner was [[John Ellis (executioner)|John Ellis]], one of the United Kingdom's hangmen at that time.<ref>[http://www.capitalpunishmentuk.org/ireland.html Southern Irish executions 1900-1954], capitalpunishmentuk.org; accessed 1 November 2008.</ref>
==Campaign for reburial== Following the [[Irish War of Independence]], Mountjoy Prison was transferred to the control of the [[Irish Free State]], which became the State of [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] in 1937. In the 1920s, the families of the dead men requested their remains be returned to them for proper burial. This effort was joined in the later 1920s by the [[National Graves Association]]. Through the efforts of the Association, the graves of the men were identified in 1934, and in 1996 a [[Celtic cross]] was erected in [[Glasnevin Cemetery]] to commemorate them.<ref>[http://www.nga.ie/history.htm Source 1. above] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071120173433/http://www.nga.ie/history.htm |date=November 20, 2007 }}</ref>
==State funeral== [[Image:The Forgotten Ten.jpg|thumb|The grave of nine of the Forgotten Ten in Glasnevin Cemetery, Dublin]] The campaign to rebury the men dragged on for 80 years from their deaths. Following an intense period of negotiations, the Irish government relented. Plans to exhume the bodies of the 10 men were announced on 1 November 2000, the 80th anniversary of the execution of Kevin Barry. On 14 October 2001, the Forgotten Ten were afforded full state honours, with a private service at Mountjoy Prison for the families of the dead, a [[requiem mass]] at [[St Mary's Pro-Cathedral]] and burial in [[Glasnevin Cemetery]].<ref>''New York Times'', 15 October 2001.</ref>
According to ''[[The Guardian]]'', some criticised the event as glorifying militant [[Irish republicanism]].<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2001/oct/15/northernireland.ireland Dublin State Funeral for IRA Men], Guardian.co.uk; accessed 1 November 2008.</ref> It coincided with the [[Fianna Fáil]] [[Ardfheis|party conference]].<ref name="guardian">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2001/oct/15/northernireland.ireland|title=Dublin state funeral for IRA men|author=Rosie Cowan|work=the Guardian|accessdate=3 November 2015}}</ref>
The progress of the cortège through the centre of Dublin was witnessed by crowds estimated as being in the tens of thousands who broke into spontaneous applause as the coffins passed.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ireland/1359518/Ahern-defends-1921-IRA-men's-state-funeral.html Ahern defends 1921 IRA men's state funeral ] 14 Oct 2001 Telegraph.co.uk : Accessed 1 November 2008</ref> On [[O'Connell Street]], a lone piper played a lament as the cortege paused outside the [[General Post Office (Dublin)|General Post Office]], the focal point of the 1916 [[Easter Rising]].<ref name="guardian" /> In his homily during the requiem mass, [[Cardinal (Catholicism)|Cardinal]] [[Cahal Daly]], a long-time critic of [[Provisional Irish Republican Army|the IRA campaign]] in [[Northern Ireland]], insisted that there was a clear distinction between the conflict of 1916–22 and the paramilitary-led violence of the previous 30 years:
{{quote| The true inheritors today of the ideals of the men and women of 1916 to 1922 are those who are explicitly and visibly committed to leaving the physical force tradition behind... Surely this state funeral can be an occasion for examination of conscience about the ideals of the men who died, and about our responsibility for translating those ideals into today's realities.<ref>[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D06EFDD113FF936A25753C1A9679C8B63&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=all Irish Rebury 10 Republicans Hanged by British in 1920s], New York Times; accessed 1 November 2008</ref>}}
In his graveside oration the [[Taoiseach]] [[Bertie Ahern]] echoed these sentiments and also paid tribute to the Ten:{{quote|These 10 young men were executed during the War of Independence. The country was under tremendous pressure at the time. There was a united effort. Meanwhile, elected by the people, Dáil Éireann was developing, in spite of a war going on. Democracy was being put to work. Independent civic institutions, including the Dáil courts, were beginning to function. Before their deaths, the ten had seen the light of freedom. They understood that Ireland would be free and independent.<ref>[http://homepage.eircom.net/~dankiely/pressreleases.html PRESS RELEASE: 17 October 2001], eircom.net; accessed 1 November 2008.</ref>}}
The [[List of Irish state funerals|state funeral]], broadcast live on national television and radio, was only the 13th since independence.<ref>[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D06EFDD113FF936A25753C1A9679C8B63&n=Top/Reference/Times%20Topics/Organizations/I/Irish%20Republican%20Army New York Times article], 15 October 15, 2001.</ref> Patrick Maher would not be reburied with his comrades. In accordance with his wishes, and those of his family, he was reinterred in [[Ballylanders]], [[County Limerick]].<ref>[http://www.taoiseach.gov.ie/index.asp?locID=383&docID=511 Patrick Maher reference] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071202182547/http://www.taoiseach.gov.ie/index.asp?locID=383&docID=511 |date=December 2, 2007 }}, taoiseach.gov.ie; accessed 19 November 2015.</ref>
A feature length [[Irish language]] documentary on the re-interments, ''An Deichniúr Dearmadta'' (''The Forgotten Ten'') aired on [[TG4]] on 28 March 2002.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hcl.harvard.edu/hfa/films/2003marapr/biff.html|title=Harvard Film Archive|work=harvard.edu|accessdate=3 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tcd.ie/irishfilm/showfilm.php?fid=51577|title=Irish Film & TV Research Online - Trinity College Dublin|work=tcd.ie|accessdate=3 November 2015}}</ref>
An episode of the BBC series ''[[Who Do You Think You Are? (UK TV series)|Who Do you Think You Are?]]'' with [[Boy George]] describes the life of Thomas Bryan, who was his great uncle.

[[File:Hans Heiling.jpg|400px|right|thumb|Hans-Heiling-Felsen]] '''Hans Heiling''' (Jan Svatoš in [[Czech language|Czech]]) is a legendary person in [[Germany|German]] and [[Bohemia]]n mythology.
The stories originate from German inhabitants of [[Loket (Sokolov District)|Loket]] (now in the [[Czech Republic]]). The son of a water fairy from the river [[Ohře]], who taught him to master magic and command spirits. Once he had become rich and powerful, he ordered the spirits under his command to build a great city. The granite rocks above the Ohře, named [[Hans-Heiling-Felsen]] (Svatošské Skály in Czech), were believed to be the ruins of this city.<ref name="cz">[http://www.cot.cz/zobrazcl.php?id=5492 COT.cz tourism site] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011002443/http://www.cot.cz/zobrazcl.php?id=5492 |date=2007-10-11 }}</ref> When Hans Heiling discovered that he could not achieve human happiness even with his supernatural powers, he discarded them and died fighting a bear. Another variant of the story is that the rock formation is a [[Petrifaction in mythology and fiction|petrified]] wedding party. A notable [[opera]] of the [[Hans Heiling|same name]] was inspired by the tale.
The poem "Ballad", by [[Gerda Mayer]], is based on the wedding party variant and appears in The Oxford Book of Story Poems.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Oxford Book of Story Poems|year=1990|publisher=OUP|isbn=0 19 276087 4|pages=27–29|editor=Michael Harrison and Christopher Stuart-Clark}}</ref>

{{lead too short|date=December 2011}}
The '''Irvine''' family were agricultural pioneers and prominent [[landowner]]s in California who gave their name to the city of [[Irvine, California]].
==James Irvine I== '''James Irvine''' (1827–1886) was born in [[County Down]], [[Ireland]] on December 27, 1827, the second to the youngest of nine children. When [[Great Famine (Ireland)|Ireland's potato crop failed]] in 1845, James Irvine and his younger brother William were among those who left for the [[United States]]. The family name is Scottish, meaning that James would have been an [[Ulster Scots people|Ulster Scot]], or [[Scotch-Irish American|Scots-Irish]]. Irvine worked for two years in [[New York City]]. In 1848 Irvine went to join the [[California Gold Rush]] as a merchant and miner. In 1854, he purchased an interest in a [[San Francisco]] commission house on Front Street, operated by a relative, John Lyons. The business was renamed "Irvine & Co., wholesale produce and grocery merchants". He began investing his profits in income-producing San Francisco real estate and soon became a wealthy man. Irvine also became a silent partner in the sheep-raising venture [[Flint, Bixby & Company]] of brothers Thomas and Benjamin Flint, and their cousin [[Bixby land companies|Llewellyn Bixby]]. The purchase of the {{convert|48800|acre|km2|adj=on}} [[Rancho San Joaquin]] in 1864 and the {{convert|47200|acre|km2|adj=on}} [[Rancho Lomas de Santiago]] in 1866 marked the beginning of their operations in Southern California. In 1867, Irvine married Henrietta Maria (Nettie) Rice, the daughter of prominent [[Cleveland, Ohio]], educator, writer, poet and State Senator [[Harvey Rice]], who was a direct descendant of [[Edmund Rice (1638)|Edmund Rice]].<ref>[http://content.cdlib.org/view?docId=kt5779q2gb&chunk.id=bioghist-1.8.3&brand=oac Guide to the Rice Family Papers]</ref> Nettie died in 1874, and Irvine married Margaret Byrne in 1880. He died March 15, 1886, and is buried in San Francisco.<ref>''Notables Of The West V2: Being The Portraits And Biographies Of The Progressive Men Of The West'', 1915, by International News Service</ref>
==James Irvine II== '''James Harvey Irvine, Sr.''' (1867–1947), son of James Irvine I and [[Harvey Rice|Henrietta Maria (Nettie) Rice]], was born October 16, 1867, in San Francisco.<ref name=Blue>[[Thomas William Herringshaw|Herringshaw, Thomas William]]. [https://books.google.com/books?id=kykEAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA293 ''American Elite and Sociologist Bluebook'', p. 293.] American Blue Book Publishers, 1922.</ref> His mother died when he was seven years old, and his father died when he was about eighteen. Between the time of James Irvine I's death in 1886 and James Irvine II's inheritance of the Southern California real estate holdings upon his twenty-fifth birthday in 1892, the properties were supervised by James Irvine I's brother, George Irvine. James II bought out Flint and the other partners, and formed the [[Irvine Company]]. He married Frances Anita Plum in 1892, and they had three children, "Jase", James Harvey Irvine Jr. (1894–1935), Katharine Helena Irvine (1894–1920) and Myford Plum Irvine (1898–1959). In 1931, James II married Mrs. Kathryn Brown White, who died in 1950.<ref>Cleland, Robert Glass. The Irvine Ranch of Orange County: 1810-1950. San Marino, Calif.: The Huntington Library, 1952, p. 147.</ref> James II lived in San Francisco until the [[1906 San Francisco earthquake]], when he relocated to the Irvine Ranch. He was a member of the [[Bohemian Club]], and kept a residence in San Francisco, at 2421 Pierce Street.<ref name=Blue/> He established the [[James Irvine Foundation]] in 1937, an entity dedicated to the "general well-being of the citizens and residents of the state of California." James II owned nearly a third of the land in present-day [[Orange County, California|Orange County]]. The city of [[Irvine, California|Irvine]] (formerly Myford) is named after him. He died of [[Bright's disease]] in 1947.<ref>[http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~npmelton/sfbirvi.htm James Irvine II]</ref>
==James Irvine III== '''James Harvey Irvine, Jr.''' (1894–1935) was groomed since a young man to take over the Ranch. He married Madeline Agassiz in 1914, but they were divorced in 1928. He married Athalie Richardson (1903–1993) in 1929, and they had one daughter, Athalie Anita "Joan" Irvine (1933– ). When James Irvine III died of tuberculosis in 1935, James II set up the James Irvine Foundation, a charitable organization to hold controlling stock in the Irvine Company. When James II died in 1947, Myford Plum Irvine (1898–1959),<ref>[http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GSmid=1380347&GRid=8286758& Myford Plum Irvine @ find a grave]</ref> James II's only surviving child, took over the presidency of the Irvine Company.<ref>{{cite book |last=Brower |first=Martin A |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=The Irvine Ranch : a time for people : a 50-year overview of the development of the Irvine Ranch |year=1994 |publisher= |quote= | url= |isbn=978-0-9641326-0-3 }} </ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Cleland |first=Robert Glass |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=The Irvine Ranch |year= 2003|publisher= The Huntington Library Classics|quote= | url= |isbn=978-0-87328-015-0 }} </ref>

Irvine fishing at his Flying D Ranch in Bozeman, Montana] *[http://web.ocpl.org/digitalmedia/v/HistoricalImages/WLR010.jpg.html Francis Anita Plum Irvine (1862-1909) wife of James Harvey Irvine] *[http://web.ocpl.org/digitalmedia/v/HistoricalImages/WLR012.jpg.html James Irvine Jr., Kathryn Helena Irvine and Myford Plum Irvine] *[http://web.ocpl.org/digitalmedia/v/HistoricalImages/OCP_Cogan_011.jpg.html Irvine brothers James Harvey Jr. (Jase) and Myford swimming at the water storage tank, Irvine Ranch, ca. 1905] *[http://web.ocpl.org/digitalmedia/v/HistoricalImages/WLR011.jpg.html James Harvey Irvine, Jr. and Kathryn Helena Irvine] *[http://web.ocpl.org/digitalmedia/v/HistoricalImages/OCP_Cogan_005.jpg.html Myford Irvine digging out stuck car, Irvine Ranch, ca. 1936] *[http://web.ocpl.org/digitalmedia/v/HistoricalImages/WLR031.jpg.html Myford and Thelma Irvine] *[http://web.ocpl.org/digitalmedia/v/HistoricalImages/WLR025.jpg.html Joan Irvine as a child in wheatfield] *[http://web.ocpl.org/digitalmedia/v/HistoricalImages/WLR024.jpg.html Athalie Richardson Irvine Clarke and Joan Irvine Smith at Irvine Cove] *[http://web.ocpl.org/digitalmedia/v/HistoricalImages/WLR026.jpg.html Joan Irvine marriage to Charles Swinden with Linda, Gloria, Myford Irvine] *[http://web.ocpl.org/digitalmedia/v/HistoricalImages/WLR023.jpg.html Joan Irvine Smith with Athalie Richardson Irvine Clarke] *[http://web.ocpl.org/digitalmedia/v/HistoricalImages/WLR021.jpg.html Athalie Richardson Irvine Clarke]

{{Portal|Ancient Near East}} '''Kupanta-Kurunta''' was the first recorded [[king]] of [[Arzawa]], in the late 15th century BC. He was defeated by [[Tudhaliya I]] and [[Arnuwanda I]].<ref>''The Routledge Handbook of The People and Places of Ancient Western Asia'' by Trevor Bryce</ref> He then attacked Arnuwanda's restive vassal [[Madduwatta]] at [[Zippasla]]. He had a daughter, who married Madduwatta.
Another '''Kupanta-Kurunta''' was born in the 1330s or 1320s BC at [[Mira (Anatolia)|Mira]] in western [[Anatolia]], in one of the princely families. His father joined a coup against king [[Mašḫuiluwa]]. The [[Hittites|Hittite]] king [[Suppiluliuma I]] married Mašḫuiluwa to his daughter Muwatti and reinstalled him. Kupanta-Kurunta's father apparently died or was exiled soon after. Mašḫuiluwa then asked Suppiluliuma's successor [[Mursili II]] if he could adopt Kupanta-Kurunta as a son.
Mira remained a Hittite ally against [[Uhha-Ziti]] of Arzawa; but two years after [[Mursili's eclipse]] (which would mean 1310 BC) Mira rebelled under influence from "Great-House-Father" (probably an adventurer from Masa). Mursili quashed this rebellion, transferred Mašḫuiluwa to a priesthood in [[Hittites|Hittite]] territory, and installed Kupanta-Kurunta as king.
In the early 13th century BC, [[Muwatalli II]] signed a treaty with Alaksandu of [[Wilusa]]. In it, he informed Alaksandu that he viewed Kupanta-Kurunta as the son of Muwatti and so a member of the Hittite royal family.
Kupanta-Kurunta is possibly the recipient of the [[Milawata letter]].
Kupanta-Kurunta apparently supported [[Hattusili III]] over Hattusili's nephew Urhi-Tessup, "[[Mursili III]]". After Hattusili attained the kingdom, Kupanta-Kurunta received a letter from Pharaoh [[Rameses II]] which was copied to Hattusili. In it, the Pharaoh reassured Kupanta-Kurunta that [[Egypt]] remained a full ally of [[Hittite Empire|Hatti]] and entertained no plans to aid Urhi-Tessup in any further adventures.<ref>''Letters of the Great Kings of the Ancient Near East'' by [[Trevor Bryce]]</ref>

'''LOVEINT''' is the practice of [[intelligence service]] employees making use of their extensive monitoring capabilities to spy on their [[love interest]] or [[spouse]]. The term was coined in resemblance to intelligence terminology such as [[Signals Intelligence|SIGINT]], [[COMINT]] or [[HUMINT]].
== National Security Agency == The term LOVEINT originated at the [[National Security Agency|NSA]], where approximately one such incident has been reported per year. In 2013, eight had been reported in the past decade, and they are the lion's share of unauthorized accesses reported by the NSA.<ref name="cnet">{{cite web|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-13578_3-57605051-38/nsa-offers-details-on-loveint-thats-spying-on-lovers-exes/ |title=NSA offers details on 'LOVEINT' (that's spying on lovers, exes) |author=Edward Moyer |work=CNET |date=2013-09-27 |accessdate=2014-03-23 |archivedate=2014-03-23 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6OHk7ld6C?url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-13578_3-57605051-38/nsa-offers-details-on-loveint-thats-spying-on-lovers-exes/ |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Most incidents are self-reported, for example during a [[polygraph]] test. The NSA sanctions them with administrative action, up to termination of employment.<ref name="blogs.wsj-loveint">{{cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/washwire/2013/08/23/nsa-officers-sometimes-spy-on-love-interests/ |title=NSA Officers Spy on Love Interests |author=Siobhan Gorman |work=Washington Wire |publisher=The Wallstreet Journal |date=2013-08-23 |accessdate=2014-03-23 |archivedate=2014-03-23 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6OHkHTCmo?url=https://blogs.wsj.com/washwire/2013/08/23/nsa-officers-sometimes-spy-on-love-interests/ |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="washingtonpost-loveint">{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-switch/wp/2013/08/24/loveint-when-nsa-officers-use-their-spying-power-on-love-interests/ |title=LOVEINT: When NSA officers use their spying power on love interests |author=Andrea Peterson |work=The Washington Post |date=2013-08-24 |accessdate=2014-03-23 |archivedate=2014-03-23 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6OHkYSmlK?url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-switch/wp/2013/08/24/loveint-when-nsa-officers-use-their-spying-power-on-love-interests/ |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="abcnews-loveint">{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/headlines/2013/09/loveint-given-immense-powers-nsa-employees-super-cyber-stalked-their-crushes/ |title=‘LoveINT’: Given Immense Powers, NSA Employees Super Cyber-Stalked Their Crushes |author=Lee Ferran |work=American Broadcasting Company |date=2013-09-27 |accessdate=2014-03-23 |archivedate=2014-03-23 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6OHkfSDh5?url=http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/headlines/2013/09/loveint-given-immense-powers-nsa-employees-super-cyber-stalked-their-crushes/ |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="nbcnews-loveint">{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/investigations/loveint-nsa-letter-discloses-employee-eavesdropping-girlfriends-spouses-v20709855 |title='Loveint': NSA letter discloses employee eavesdropping on girlfriends, spouses |author=National Broadcasting Company |work=National Broadcasting Company |date=2013-09-27 |accessdate=2014-03-23 |archivedate=2014-03-23 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6OHkoKNmP?url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/investigations/loveint-nsa-letter-discloses-employee-eavesdropping-girlfriends-spouses-v20709855 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> In five of the cases, the NSA employee resigned, preempting any administrative action. In two other cases, they retired.<ref name="cnet"/> The worst administrative sanction handed out was "a reduction in pay for two months, a reduction in grade, and access to classified information being revoked". One case was forwarded to the [[United States Department of Justice|Department of Justice]], which however declined to prosecute.<ref name="slate-loveint">{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/future_tense/2013/09/27/loveint_how_nsa_spies_snooped_on_girlfriends_lovers_and_first_dates.html |title=Loveint: How NSA spies snooped on girlfriends, lovers, and first dates. |author=Ryan Gallagher |work=Future Tense |publisher=Slate |date=2013-09-27 |accessdate=2014-03-23 |archivedate=2014-03-23 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6OHkwh19K?url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/future_tense/2013/09/27/loveint_how_nsa_spies_snooped_on_girlfriends_lovers_and_first_dates.html |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
== German Federal Intelligence Service == In September 2007, it was reported that an employee of the German [[Bundesnachrichtendienst|Federal Intelligence Service]] abused his monitoring powers to read the email-traffic of his wife's lover.<ref name="berliner-zeitung-loveint-bnd">{{cite web|url=http://www.berliner-zeitung.de/archiv/bka-reform---das-bundeskriminalamt-soll-per-gesetz-mehr-befugnisse-bei-der-terrorabwehr-bekommen--neue-fahndungsmethoden-sollen-die-jagd-auf-staatsfeinde-erleichtern--beamter-unter-verdacht,10810590,10501420.html |title=BKA-REFORM - Das Bundeskriminalamt soll per Gesetz mehr Befugnisse bei der Terrorabwehr bekommen. Neue Fahndungsmethoden sollen die Jagd auf Staatsfeinde erleichtern.: Beamter unter Verdacht |author=Andreas Förster |work=Berliner Zeitung |date=2007-08-31 |language=German |accessdate=2014-03-16 |archivedate=2011-03-26 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xTVvZeSU?url=http://www.berlinonline.de/berliner-zeitung/archiv/.bin/dump.fcgi/2007/0831/politik/0062/index.html |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>

{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox civilian attack | title = Lambeth slavery case | location = [[Lambeth]], [[South London]], [[England]] | date = {{spaced ndash}}25 October 2013 | time = | timezone = | coordinates = | type = [[Slavery]], [[domestic servitude]] | victims = {{Plainlist| * Aishah Wahab<ref name="Sawer">Patrick Sawer, et al [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/10486213/How-Chairman-Mao-of-Brixton-built-his-sect-of-slaves.html "How Chairman Mao of Brixton built his sect of 'slaves’"], telegraph.co.uk, 2013</ref> * Josephine Herivel<ref>Martin Evans, et al [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/10476943/Irish-slave-revealed-as-daughter-of-Bletchley-Park-code-breaking-hero.html "Irish 'slave' revealed as daughter of Bletchley Park code breaking hero "], telegraph.co.uk, 26 November 2013</ref> * Rosie Morgan-Davies<ref name="Sawer"/>
}} | susperps = {{Plainlist| * Aravindan Balakrishnan * Chanda Balakrishnan }} }} On 21 November 2013 [[Metropolitan Police Service|Metropolitan Police]] from the [[National Crime Agency#Organisational Structure|Human Trafficking Unit]] arrested two suspects at a residential address in [[Lambeth]], [[South London]]. A 73-year-old ethnic Indian [[Singaporean]] man, Aravindan Balakrishnan, and a 67-year-old [[Tanzanian]]<ref name = "growing up"/> woman, his wife, Chanda Pattni, had been investigated for [[slavery]] and [[domestic servitude]].<ref name="Halliday"/><ref name="Standard"/> The case centred around the [[Workers' Institute of Marxism–Leninism–Mao Zedong Thought]] commune which was led by Balakrishnan. In the early 1980s after a police raid, Balakrishnan decided to move the group's activities underground. Balakrishnan's control over his followers intensified and the commune became a prison to his followers. On 25 October 2013, three women were rescued from the commune. These were: a 69-year-old [[Malaysians in the United Kingdom|Malaysian]] woman (later revealed to be Aishah Wahab),<ref name="Sawer"/> a 57-year-old [[Republic of Ireland|Irish]] woman (Josephine Herivel) and a 30-year-old [[United Kingdom|British]] woman (Katy Morgan-Davies).<ref name="Standard">{{cite news |title=Women victims 'held for 30 years' |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/panewsfeeds/women-victims-held-for-30-years-8954976.html |publisher=London Evening Standard |date=21 November 2013 |accessdate=21 November 2013 }}</ref> Katy Morgan-Davies was born into the sect and hadn't experienced the outside world until her release.
==Perpetrator== '''Aravindan Balakrishnan''' (known to his followers as "'''Comrade Bala'''") was born in [[Kerala]], [[India]] but migrated to [[Singapore]], [[British Malaya|Malaya]], where his father was a soldier, when he was 10.<ref name="Ward-Tele">{{cite news|last1=Ward|first1=Victoria|title=Aravindan Balakrishnan: the Maoist cult leader who used brutal violence and rape to strip women of their dignity|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/12031312/Aravindan-Balakrishnan-the-Maoist-cult-leader-who-used-brutal-violence-and-rape-to-strip-women-of-their-dignity.html|accessdate=5 June 2017|work=The Telegraph|date=4 December 2015}}</ref> Balakrishnan was a student at [[Raffles Institution]] and later the [[University of Singapore]], where although gaining a reputation as a "quiet chap",<ref name="Reuters-AO">{{cite news|author1=Reuters|title=UK Maoist cult leader raped followers, enslaved daughter|url=http://www.asiaone.com/world/uk-maoist-cult-leader-raped-followers-enslaved-daughter|accessdate=5 June 2017|work=AsiaOne|date=13 November 2015}}</ref> he became increasingly politically active and believed that he would have been imprisoned in Singapore had he openly admitted to being a [[communist]].<ref name="Ward-Tele" /> In 1977, while living in London, His Singaporean citizenship – which he gained in 1960 – was revoked due to his leadership of the [[Workers' Institute of Marxism–Leninism–Mao Zedong Thought]], which the [[Ministry of Home Affairs (Singapore)|Ministry of Home Affairs]] accused of engaging in "activities which are prejudicial to the security" of Singapore, and denounced him as a radical "closely associated with [[Eurocommunists]]".<ref name="Reuters-AO" /> The authorities claimed that Balakrishnan and others, many of them former Singaporean students he had associated with in London, were plotting to overthrow Singapore's leader, [[Lee Kuan Yew]].<ref name="Ward-Tele" />
Despite believing the United Kingdom to be a [[fascist state]] due to its treatment of the people of Singapore during the [[Malayan Emergency]], Balakrishnan emigrated to the UK in 1963 on a [[British Council]] scholarship to study at the [[London School of Economics]], and married his wife Chandra in 1971.<ref name="Ward-Tele" /> Over the years he built up a following by giving lectures and staging various [[sit-in]]s and protests. He was a regular attendee at [[London]] demonstrations, where he waved banners depicting the Chinese leader [[Mao Zedong]] and addressed the crowds.<ref name="Ward-Tele" />
In 1974, Balakrishnan and his "small clique" were expelled from the [[Communist Party of England (Marxist–Leninist)]] on account of "their pursuance of conspiratorial and [[wikt:splittist|splittist]] activities ... spreading [[social fascist]] slanders against the Party and the proletarian movement" and attempting "to put themselves above the discipline of the Party".<ref name="CPE(M-L) statement">[http://www.marxists.org/history/erol/uk.hightide/cpestatements.htm "Statements of the National Executive Committee, CPE (ML)"], ''The Marxist-Leninist'', 1:1, September 1974, reprinted at marxists.org. Quoted in Nick Cohen [http://blogs.spectator.co.uk/nick-cohen/2013/11/cultists-communists-too-close-to-us-for-comfort/ "Cultists & communists – too close to us for comfort"], ''The Spectator'' (blog), 25 November 2013</ref> The CPE(M–L) "repudiated the metaphysical logic harmfully promoted" by Balakrishnan in "opposition to dialectical materialism and the concrete analysis of concrete conditions".<ref name="CPE(M-L) statement"/> In response, Balakrishnan set up the Workers' Institute and launched his own publication, the ''South London Workers' Bulletin'', which accused the CPE(M–L) of being "fascists" and "agents of imperialism".<ref name="Ford-WW-989">{{cite news|last1=Ford|first1=Eddie|title=Maoist 'slaves': Combating the fascist state in Brixton - Weekly Worker|url=http://weeklyworker.co.uk/worker/989/maoist-slaves-combating-the-fascist-state-in-brixt/|accessdate=5 June 2017|work=Weekly Worker|issue=989|date=5 December 2013}}</ref>
Between 1974 and 1976, his followers attempted to "build revolutionary stable base areas in working-class communities",<ref name="On Building a">{{cite news|author1=Workers’ Institute of Marxism-Leninism-Mao Zedong Thought|title=On Building a Revolutionary Stable Base Area|url=https://www.marxists.org/history/erol/uk.hightide/stable-base.htm|work=Encyclopedia of Anti-Revisionism On-Line|year=1977}}</ref> primarily [[South London]], and worked in ordinary jobs. Balakrishnan discouraged his followers from joining [[trade unions]], describing them as agents of the "imperialist fascist bourgeoisie".<ref name="Smith-Conv">{{cite news|last1=Smith|first1=Evan|title=Inside the paranoid Maoist cults of 1970s Britain|url=http://theconversation.com/inside-the-paranoid-maoist-cults-of-1970s-britain-20739|accessdate=5 June 2017|work=The Conversation|date=28 November 2013}}</ref>
Eventually, after the more liberal members of his group drifted away, a cult of around 10 female members formed around him. The collective moved to Brixton in 1976, under the title [[Workers Institute of Marxism-Leninism-Mao Zedong Thought]].<ref name="Ward-Tele" /> Following [[Mao Zedong#Death and aftermath|Mao's death in 1976]], the Institute built the Mao Zedong Memorial Centre at 140 Acre Lane, [[Brixton]], which also functioned as a communist collective of "thirteen comrades", with "13 members living on the premises, half in paid work, six doing full-time revolutionary work, with a strong emphasis on women taking a leading role (apart from leading the Party Committee headed by Bala)".<ref name="On Building a" /><ref name="Smith-Conv" /><ref>{{cite news|title=High Tide: The Consolidation of Maoism by the Late 1970’s|url=https://www.marxists.org/history/erol/uk.hightide/|accessdate=5 June 2017|work=Encyclopedia of Anti-Revisionism On-Line}}</ref> Members were handed a rota of chores and only allowed to go out in pairs, which Balakrishnan claimed was because the area they lived in was "notorious for violence" and "anything could happen".<ref name="Ward-Tele" /><ref name="Ward-Tele2">{{cite news|last1=Ward|first1=Victoria|title=Maoist 'cult' leader denies rape as he claims female commune members competed for his affections|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/12019410/Maoist-cult-leader-denies-rape-as-he-claims-female-commune-members-competed-for-his-affections.html|accessdate=5 June 2017|work=Telegraph|date=26 November 2016|language=en}}</ref>
Following a police raid on the Memorial Centre in March 1978, which the group claimed involved "over 200 police", including officers from the [[Special Patrol Group]], "under the pretext of searching for drugs", the Workers' Institute effectively went underground, with the remaining members being convinced to end all contact with others and maintain an intense level of secrecy.<ref name="Smith-Conv" /> Family members were later branded fascist agents and ostracised,<ref name="Ward-Tele" /> and Balakrishnan and his captives moved to a number of properties during this time as a means for him to escape detection from the authorities.<ref name="Smith-Conv" /> Balakrishnan convinced his followers that everything was controlled by him from the sun, the moon, wind and fires; that he could overthrow governments, control natural disasters, and make people live or die.<ref name="Ward-Tele" /> In order to progress his cause, Balakrishnan invented "JACKIE" (an acronym for [[Jehovah]], [[Allah]], [[Christ]], [[Krishna]] and [[Eknath Easwaran|Immortal Easwaran]]) – a type of dangerous, mystical machine that monitored all thought and could control minds.<ref name="Cooke">{{cite news|last1=Cooke|first1=Rachel|title=My 30 years as prisoner of a London cult|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2017/jan/22/katy-morgan-davies-interview-balakrishnan-cult-brixton-survivor|accessdate=5 June 2017|work=The Guardian|date=22 January 2017}}</ref>
Balakrishnan began sexually abusing two of the women in 1979, often physically beating them and making others watch as he did so. All of the women were beaten and four (not including his wife) were said to have been sexually assaulted or engaged with sexual relations with him.<ref name="Ward-Tele" /> Balakrishnan forced the women to swallow his ejaculate as it was "the elixir of life", and claimed the women he sexually abused had been trying to seduce him out of "jealousy" for his lover.<ref name="Ward-Tele" /><ref name="Ward-Tele2" />
==Victims== *[[Katy Morgan-Davies]] - born in 1983, she was originally named Prem Maopinduzi Davies. She began calling herself "Rosie" in her teens. She has subsequently changed her name to Katy Morgan-Davies, after the American singer [[Katy Perry]]. She is the biological daughter of Balakrishnan and Sian Davies.<ref name = "growing up">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/resources/idt-b0af7ef5-1031-4e1f-a3ac-b3c21ef0f932|title=Growing up a prisoner in a cult|date=26 January 2017|accessdate=28 January 2017|author=Vanessa Engle|publisher=BBC}}</ref> Morgan-Davies was brought up entirely isolated from the outside world and never went to a nursery, school, dentist or doctor. She was not told who her parents were. The commune members taught her to read and write.<ref name=bbc2>https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/resources/idt-b0af7ef5-1031-4e1f-a3ac-b3c21ef0f932</ref>
*[[Sian Davies]] - in the early 1980s, after joining the commune, she had a sexual relationship with Balakrishnan. On Christmas Eve 1996, Morgan-Davies remembered seeing Davies bound and gagged on the living room for trying to escape. Later, she fell out of a top floor bathroom window and was taken to hospital. In hospital she suffered a rapid decline in her mental health and fell into a coma. She died eight months later. After the fall, her family were told she had gone to India to do charity work.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}} At the time of Davie's death her daughter, Morgan-Davies, did not know she was her mother.
*[[Aishah Wahab]] - a [[Malaysians|Malaysian]] woman who moved to the United Kingdom at the age of 24 to study, joining the group shortly after.<ref name = "growing up"/> Aishah was reportedly so drawn in by Balakrishnan's Marxist rhetoric that she left her fiancé and moved in with the collective.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}}
*[[Oh Kar Eng]] - nurse from [[Malaysia]] who had followed Balakrishnan from the 1970s. She hit her head on a cupboard in 2001 and suffered a stroke. No medical treatment was allowed by the commune and she died the next day.{{r|bbc}} The police were not informed of the accident. Her family were not told about her cremation, and they were told the commune did not have their ashes when in fact they were in a lockup garage in West Norwood.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}}
*[[Josephine Herivel]] - known as Josie, was a violinist studying at the [[Royal College of Music]] before she joined the group.<ref name = "growing up"/> Her father, [[John Herivel]] was one of the [[Bletchley Park]] [[codebreakers]] who helped Britain and its allies win [[World War II]]. She is believed to have moved to London in the 1970s and disowned her family after becoming involved with the Workers' Institute of Marxism–Leninism–Mao Zedong Thought.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}} Herivel initiated the escape plan after becoming concerned with Morgan-Davies rapid weight loss (which was due to undiagnosed diabetes). Medical treatment was not permitted by the commune. Herivel secretly phoned a helpline after memorizing the number from a television program. Herivel has denounced the Balakrishnan sentencing, claiming he has been framed by the state.{{r|bbc}}
==Imprisonment and rescue== The two older victims are believed to have met Balakrishnan in [[London]] through, according to police, a shared political ideology,<ref name="Evans">Martin Evans [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/10472632/Slavery-case-suspects-named-as-former-Maoist-collective-leaders.html "Slavery case: suspects named as former Maoist collective leaders"], telegraph.co.uk, 25 November 2013</ref> as he was the leader of the [[Workers' Institute of Marxism–Leninism–Mao Zedong Thought]].<ref>[http://www.channel4.com/news/slave-house-couple-lambeth-leaders-1970s-political-cult 'Slave' house couple 'leaders of 1970s political cult'"], ''[[Channel 4 News]]'', 25 November 2013</ref> The women were not being physically restrained, but held by "invisible handcuffs" after being subjected to [[Mind control|brainwashing]], [[Psychological abuse|emotional abuse]] and [[physical abuse]] by their captors.<ref name="Standard_2">{{cite news |title=London slave women endured 30 years of beatings, brainwashing and emotional control |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/crime/london-slave-women-endured-30-years-of-beatings-brainwashing-and-emotional-control-8956001.html |publisher=London Evening Standard |date=22 November 2013 |accessdate=23 November 2013 |first=Justin |last=Davenport}}</ref> The three women, who are not related, are said to have been held captive for more than 30 years with the youngest of the three thought to have spent her whole life in servitude.<ref name="BBC">{{cite news |title=Women 'held as slaves for 30 years' |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-25040741 |publisher=BBC News |date=21 November 2013 |accessdate=21 November 2013 }}</ref> However it has not yet been established if she was born in the house from where she was rescued.<ref name="BBC"/> The police were tipped off by [[Freedom Charity]] who contacted police following a phone call they had received on 18 October, during which a woman stated that she'd been held unwillingly for more than 30 years.<ref name="Standard_2"/><ref name="Irish">{{cite news |title=Irishwoman raises alarm after being held captive ‘for decades’ in south London home |url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/irishwoman-raises-alarm-after-being-held-captive-for-decades-in-south-london-home-29773908.html |work=[[Irish Independent]] |publisher=Independent News & Media |date=21 November 2013 |accessdate=21 November 2013 }}</ref> [[Aneeta Prem]] of Freedom Charity confirmed that the Irish woman made contact with the charity after watching the [[ITV (TV channel)|ITV]] television documentary ''Forced to Marry'' about [[forced marriage]] in the United Kingdom.<ref name="Irish"/><ref>{{cite news |title=Lambeth 'slaves rescue': Woman 'called Freedom Charity after watching TV documentary on forced marriage' |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/lambeth-slaves-rescue-woman-called-2836476 |work=Daily Mirror |publisher=Trinity Mirror |date=23 November 2013 |accessdate=23 November 2013 |first=James |last=Robertson |first2=Mark |last2=Jefferies }}</ref> The women, who are said to be "highly traumatised", are now in safe accommodation.<ref name="BBC"/>
The two suspects were bailed until April 2014,<ref name="Shaw">Danny Shaw [https://twitter.com/DannyShawBBC/status/425657327706861568] twitter.com, 21 January 2014</ref> and were unable to return to the three-bedroom flat they rented from a housing association.<ref name="Evans"/>
On 11 December 2014, it emerged that Balakrishnan had been charged with offences relating to cruelty to a person under 16, four counts of rape and 17 counts of indecent assault. Balakrishnan appeared before Westminster magistrates on 17 December 2014.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-30431988 "Man charged in London 'slavery' inquiry"], BBC News, 11 December 2014</ref> His wife, Chanda Pattni, was released earlier in 2014, as there was considered to be insufficient evidence for a realistic prospect of conviction.<ref>Josh Halliday [https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2014/dec/11/london-slavery-case-cps-charges-ravindan-alakrishnan "London ‘slavery’ case: CPS charges Aravindan Balakrishnan"], ''The Guardian'', 11 December 2014</ref>
Balakrishnan's trial started on 11 November 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/11990783/Maoist-cult-leader-kept-daughter-as-slave-in-south-London-for-30-years-court-hears.html |title=Maoist cult leader sexually assaulted followers and kept daughter as slave for 30 years, court hears |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date= 12 November 2015 |author=Gordon Rayner |accessdate= 26 November 2015}}</ref> During his trial, he acted as the only defence witness, and told jurors that a challenge to his leadership resulted in the 1986 [[Space Shuttle Challenger disaster]], and that JACKIE was responsible for the death of a Malaysian prime minister and the election of [[Jeremy Corbyn]] as [[Leader of the Labour Party (UK)|Leader of the Labour Party]].<ref name="Ward-Tele" />
On 4 December 2015, Balakrishnan was convicted of child cruelty, false imprisonment, four counts of rape, six counts of indecent assault and two counts of assault.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2015/dec/04/commune-leader-aravindan-balakrishnan-guilty-of-child-cruelty "Maoist cult leader guilty of child cruelty and sexual assaults"], ''The Guardian'', 4 December 2015</ref> On 29 January 2016, Balakrishnan was jailed for 23 years. <ref>{{Cite web|title = Maoist cult leader Aravindan Balakrishnan jailed for 23 years - BBC News|url = https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-35443423|website = BBC News|access-date = 2016-01-29|language = en-GB}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em|refs= <ref name=bbc>https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/resources/idt-b0af7ef5-1031-4e1f-a3ac-b3c21ef0f932</ref>
<ref name="Halliday">{{cite news |title=Three women rescued after 'decades of slavery' in south London home |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/nov/21/women-rescued-decades-slavery-south-london |publisher=The Guardian |date=21 November 2013 |accessdate=21 November 2013 |first=Josh |last=Halliday |first2=Peter |last2=Walker}}</ref> }}

page.title: List of 301 geniuses by IQ (Catharine Cox Miles)

revision.text:
The list of 301 geniuses by [[intelligence quotient]] below is an estimation by [[Catharine Cox Miles]] published in the "Early Mental Traits of Three Hundred Geniuses (12A-AII table)" during 1926.M. Cox, Catharine (1926). "Early Mental Traits of Three Hundred Geniuses (Genetic Studies of Genius Series)" (en inglés). Stanford University Press. pp. 60a-60f. Original estimate is based in the [[historiometric]] method of [[Francis Galton]] and the [[Stanford–Binet Intelligence Scales|Stanford Binet Scale]] I (1916). The list is corrected and actualized due the [[Flynn effect]] during 1916 to 2003 and contains a convertion of Stanford Binet to Weschler based in inverse error function formulas and rarity chart tables (16SD to 15SD)..James R. Flynn, Massive IQ Gains in 14 Nations: What IQ Tests Really Measure, Psychological Bulletin, 1987, Vol. 101, No. 2, pp. 171-191Kush, J. C. (2005). Review of the Stanford-Binet Intelligence Scales: Fifth Edition. In R. A. Spies & B. S. Plake (Eds.), The sixteenth mental measurements yearbook (pp. 979–984). Lincoln: University of Nebraska. Rarity example with erfc-1 formula to [[Johann Wolfgang von Goethe]] IQ with Stanford Binet (16SD)ː
16 \sqrt{2} \operatorname{erfc}^{-1} \left( \frac{2}{14,400,000} \right) +100 =184 Rarity example with erfc-1 formula to [[Johann Wolfgang von Goethe]] IQ with Weschler (15SD)ː
15 \sqrt{2} \operatorname{erfc}^{-1} \left( \frac{2}{14,400,000} \right) +100 =179 {| class="wikitable sortable" border="|1" ! Genius ! Cox Miles estimation (1926)
Based in [[Stanford-Binet|SB]]1 (1916) ! [[Flynn effect]] 1916-1986
Based in [[Stanford-Binet|SB]]4 Scale (1986) ! [[Flynn effect]] 1986-2003
Based in [[Stanford-Binet|SB]]5 Scale (2003) ! SB5-[[Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale|WAIS]] convertion
